Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EaSM2--Quantifying and Conveying the Risk of Prolonged Drought in Coming Decades
Award.AbstractNarration:
Drought is among the most ruinous of natural disasters and is expected to become increasingly prevalent in a warming world. In the future, natural hydroclimatic variability will be superimposed on continued human-driven changes to regional climate, with both long-term warming and regional drying likely to exacerbate droughts of the future. Among the greatest challenges of decadal prediction and climate change projection are the quantification of prolonged drought risk in vulnerable regions and the integration of knowledge about this risk into the decision-making processes of the many resource managers and other stakeholders who deal with drought.

This project focuses on a scale of drought variability - decadal to multidecadal - that is not well constrained by observations, nor well represented in models. The activity relies on the integrated use of satellite, instrumental, and paleoclimatic observations, along with climate models and analysis, to understand both the natural and human influences on drought, potential model biases, and the roles of land cover change (vegetation and dust), ocean temperatures, and other factors behind drought. The goal is to develop improved estimates of drought risk, as well as the improved partnerships between scientists and stakeholders that are required to reduce the vulnerability of society to drought. Key vulnerable regions will be identified, where natural variability and anthropogenic change combine to amplify the risk of prolonged, severe drought with large consequences: southwestern North America (US and Mexico), Australia, the Amazon, and West Africa/Sahel.

The strategy takes advantage of several unique observational, model and stakeholder resources: (1) an unprecedented number of simulations of the past millennium from a state-of-the-art Earth System Model (CESM; in addition to the CMIP5 archive); (2) an expanding set of published and emerging paleoclimate datasets from multiple proxies that reveal long observational histories of decadal-multidecadal hydroclimate variability; (3) a longstanding network of stakeholders and collaborators in the southwestern US, Mexico, and beyond with whom we can develop best practices in applying drought risk estimates to real-world problems across a broad social context; and (4) a long history of working on drought variability and stakeholder-driven.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drought has had devastating effects on human life and livelihood; it undermines agriculture, natural ecosystems, human health, energy generation, transportation, and the daily lives of residents in afflicted regions. As the world warms, regions characterized by aridity will expand. Anticipating future drought risk is complicated by the superposition of anthropogenic climate changes and substantial natural variability. Droughts on decadal-multidecadal (DM) scales pose especially difficult problems as the management and adaptation challenges are severe, yet the short observational record limits our ability to characterize and understand the physical processes causing these features. A major goal of this project was to estimate DM drought risk by explicitly identifying the contributions of natural variability and anthropogenic changes in the hydrological cycle. This task is timely and pressing for decision-makers, who use drought risk information in a multi-stress context that integrates climate information with broader concerns.

The project integrated instrumental and paleoclimatic observations, along with climate models and novel analysis techniques, to describe the full range of past hydroclimate and drought variability over the past thousand years. This led to improved understanding of both natural and human influences on drought, including the roles of land cover change, emissions of greenhouse gases and aerosols, ocean temperatures, and other physical processes. A key deliverable of the project was the creation of the Last Millennium Ensemble (LME) of simulations with the Community Earth System Model (CESM); the project also made use of large ensemble simulations of the 20th and 21st century conducted at NCAR and other modeling centers.

The role of volcanic eruptions in generating hydroclimate and ocean dynamical responses was one focus of our investigations. Major eruptions over the last millennium were shown to result in drying/wetting patterns strongly resembling the influence of the El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO), even in the absence of changes to ENSO itself. Additionally, the volcanic influence depends strongly on the nature of the eruption: changing the latitude and season of eruption occurrence can lead to very different signatures in both sea surface temperature and associated hydroclimatic change. Volcanic effects also have the potential to influence the long-term properties of drought through modulating climate variability, even though the direct effect of individual eruptions only last for a few years.

This project also gave important insights into the behavior of modes of climate variability and their relationship with DM drought. Our analysis of the CESM LME indicates that extreme eastern Pacific El Nino events are increased by greenhouse-gas emissions and land use changes in the 20th century as compared to previous centuries, with important implications for this next century. We also determined that ENSO has a much stronger influence overall on megadrought and pluvial persistence than does the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO), although AMO-driven effects are important, for example in the central U.S.

This project showed that climate change is likely to enhance the strength of ENSO teleconnections to many important regions, and specifically to the southwestern US and Australia. Interestingly, contrasts in the sign of teleconnection changes over land and ocean were also identified, suggesting a role for land surface processes in the simulated changes. The consequence of these changes is that in addition to background warming and increases in wildfire risk, year to year variability is also likely to increase, putting an additional strain on adaptation efforts under climate change.

Our application of self-organizing maps on observationally-based products, paleoclimate reconstructions, and the CESM LME as well as simulations completed by other modeling centers for the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project provided a novel means of visualizing the continuum of drought in southwestern North America. The model and data agree that the region experiences distinct droughts lasting two to three years multiple times per century, droughts last lasting five years about once per century, droughts spanning 5-10 years about once every other century, and multi-decadal drought once every few centuries. However, the models may overestimate the risk of short droughts (less than 5 year) and underestimate the risk of longer droughts (15-20 years) as compared to the paleoclimate reconstructions, suggesting a discrepancy in low-frequency hydroclimatic variability between observations, climate models and the paleoclimate record. In addition, our results indicate that most droughts are associated with a cool Pacific decadal oscillation (PDO) pattern, but persistent droughts can coincide with a variety of ocean-atmosphere states including El Nino events. Importantly, and somewhat counterintuitively, El Nino is also the most consistent part of the life cycle of the long drought events, as they set the stage for drought and also tend to terminate these features.
